Executing code
With the execute command you can make a program execute your code. You can either provide assembly instructions that will then get assembled into byte code or you can provide the byte code yourself, maybe hand-written or assembled by your favorite assembler.
The command for executing code from an assembly file for a program whose PID is 12345 looks like this:
$ proctal execute --pid=12345 < code.asm
The given instructions will be embedded at some place in memory and executed in a new stack frame in the context of the main thread. The other threads will be paused. Your code is free to modify any registers because they will be restored to their original values. Control will be given back to the program after the last instruction is executed.
If you'd rather execute byte code instead you would pass the --format option with the value bytecode.
Here's how you would execute byte code from a binary file:
$ proctal execute --pid=12345 --format=bytecode < code.bin
